title: How to Promote Humane Farming Practices

steps.headline: Buy cage-free eggs.
steps.description:
This is a simple step you can take to support poultry facilities which raise their chickens in a humane, open-air environment. At your local grocery store, look on the eggs’ packaging for a sticker or logo that reads “cage-free,” “free range,” or “organic.”
As with most humanely raised animal products, cage-free eggs with cost a couple of dollars more than eggs gathered from caged chickens. You’ll need to decide if spending the extra money to encourage humane farming practices is a choice you’d like to make.

steps.headline: Dine at restaurants that serve humanely-farmed foods.
steps.description: Many restaurants opt for a farm-to-table approach for sourcing their food, or only purchase food products from farms with humane practices. Eat at these restaurants to help support humane farming practices in your community. Be aware, though, that restaurants using humanely-farmed meat are often more expensive, due to the higher cost of the ingredients. If you’re unsure whether or not a restaurant serves meat from humane farms, it’s OK to ask. Send a polite email, or ask to speak to the chef after your meal. Say something like, “Hi, I’m only interested in eating meat products that have come from farms with humane practices. Do you know if the meat you serve falls into this category?”

steps.headline: Purchase meat products at Whole Foods stores.
steps.description: In 2011, the Whole Foods corporation began stocking products from the Global Animal Partnership, an organization which promotes humane farming practices. This program allows farms—whether corporate or family-run—to meet certain humane farming criteria in return for having their products sold in Whole Foods stores. Read the label on meat and dairy products before purchasing them. Only items marked with the “GAP” (Global Animal Partnership) logo are guaranteed to have been produced at a farm with humane practices.

steps.headline: Purchase Certified Humane products.
steps.description: The company Certified Humane works with animal farms and meat producers to ensure that certain basic humane standards are met. These include allowing animals time outside and raising animals outside of cages. Buying products at your local grocery store that have been marked with the “certified humane” logo helps support and encourage humane farming practices. Certified Humane does not raise any animals or make a profit themselves. Rather, they help connect consumers with the companies that raise food animals in humane ways. Since many of the food providers are small farmers, Certified Humane helps them compete with the large factory farms that would otherwise dominate grocery-stores meat and poultry sections.

steps.headline: Buy products bearing the “Animal Welfare Approved” logos.
steps.description: Certified Humane and the GAP are not the only organization which works with farms to encourage humane farming practices. The AWA welfare certification label indicates that meat sold with this marking has been raised in a humane farm or facility. Additionally, most products with the “AWA” marking have come from small, independent farms.

methods.name: Finding Grocery Stores that Stock Humane Farming Products

steps.headline: Search online for grocery stores that sell products from humane sources.
steps.description: Certified Humane provides an online map and search website which lets you search your local area and find grocery stores that well products marked “certified humane.” Navigate to The Certified Humane “Where to Buy” page at: https://certifiedhumane.org/take-action-for-farm-animals/shop-2/. From there, select the radius within which you’d like to search for grocery stores that sell humanely produced meat products. If you’re looking for a certain type of humanely raised meat (e.g., pork, chicken, turkey), you can make that selection from the corresponding drop-down menu as well.

steps.headline: Purchase meat products from farms that treat animals humanely.
steps.description: Rather than taking a gamble with each visit to a grocery store as to whether the meat you’re buying was raised humanely or not, purchase meat from farms that are known to have humane farming practices. Purchasing meat products from these farms will support them directly, and encourage further humane farming practices. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) maintains an online list which lists farms that use humane farming practices. View the list at: https://www.aspca.org/shopwithyourheart/consumer-resources/shop-your-heart-brand-list. All of the farms listed are “certified humane” or approved by the AWA or GAP.

steps.headline: Consider purchasing humanely farmed animal products online.
steps.description: Some farms which treat their animals humanely are too small to distribute to different states. Very small humane family farms may be too small even to distribute to local grocery stores. However, you can still support these humane farms by purchasing their products online. Check the ASPCA online list for humane farms whose goods are only available online. Humane farms whose products are available only online include: Wilde chicken jerky, pork from Belcamp Farm, and turkey from Anderson Ranches.

steps.headline: Ask your local grocery stores to stock humanely farmed products.
steps.description: If you don’t see any products marked “certified humane” (or with the AWA or GAP logos) at your local grocery store, ask the managers if they’d be willing so start stocking humanely farmed meat products. Store managers are more likely to stock humane products if they know that a demand for these products exists among their customers. Use the Certified Humane letter template to request that a grocery store stock humanely farmed products. Access the template at: http://certifiedhumane.org/wp-content/uploads/Grocer-Request-Letter-2017c-1.pdf.

steps.headline: Post on social media sites about supporting humane farming.
steps.description: Some of your professional contacts, friends, and family members may not be aware of the need for humane farming. Help promote these practices by posting about humane farming online, and encouraging others to care about the issue. For example, you could share an article on Facebook that describes humane farming practices and the ways they benefit animals’ health and well-being. Or, Tweet a link to a local farm that uses humane practices, and encourage friends and family to buy their meat from the farm.

text:
Finding Humane Products Buy cage-free eggs. This is a simple step you can take to support poultry facilities which raise their chickens in a humane, open-air environment. At your local grocery store, look on the eggs’ packaging for a sticker or logo that reads “cage-free,” “free range,” or “organic.”
As with most humanely raised animal products, cage-free eggs with cost a couple of dollars more than eggs gathered from caged chickens. You’ll need to decide if spending the extra money to encourage humane farming practices is a choice you’d like to make. Dine at restaurants that serve humanely-farmed foods. Many restaurants opt for a farm-to-table approach for sourcing their food, or only purchase food products from farms with humane practices. Eat at these restaurants to help support humane farming practices in your community. Be aware, though, that restaurants using humanely-farmed meat are often more expensive, due to the higher cost of the ingredients. If you’re unsure whether or not a restaurant serves meat from humane farms, it’s OK to ask. Send a polite email, or ask to speak to the chef after your meal. Say something like, “Hi, I’m only interested in eating meat products that have come from farms with humane practices. Do you know if the meat you serve falls into this category?” Purchase meat products at Whole Foods stores. In 2011, the Whole Foods corporation began stocking products from the Global Animal Partnership, an organization which promotes humane farming practices. This program allows farms—whether corporate or family-run—to meet certain humane farming criteria in return for having their products sold in Whole Foods stores. Read the label on meat and dairy products before purchasing them. Only items marked with the “GAP” (Global Animal Partnership) logo are guaranteed to have been produced at a farm with humane practices. Purchase Certified Humane products. The company Certified Humane works with animal farms and meat producers to ensure that certain basic humane standards are met. These include allowing animals time outside and raising animals outside of cages. Buying products at your local grocery store that have been marked with the “certified humane” logo helps support and encourage humane farming practices. Certified Humane does not raise any animals or make a profit themselves. Rather, they help connect consumers with the companies that raise food animals in humane ways. Since many of the food providers are small farmers, Certified Humane helps them compete with the large factory farms that would otherwise dominate grocery-stores meat and poultry sections. Buy products bearing the “Animal Welfare Approved” logos. Certified Humane and the GAP are not the only organization which works with farms to encourage humane farming practices. The AWA welfare certification label indicates that meat sold with this marking has been raised in a humane farm or facility. Additionally, most products with the “AWA” marking have come from small, independent farms. Finding Grocery Stores that Stock Humane Farming Products Search online for grocery stores that sell products from humane sources. Certified Humane provides an online map and search website which lets you search your local area and find grocery stores that well products marked “certified humane.” Navigate to The Certified Humane “Where to Buy” page at: https://certifiedhumane.org/take-action-for-farm-animals/shop-2/. From there, select the radius within which you’d like to search for grocery stores that sell humanely produced meat products. If you’re looking for a certain type of humanely raised meat (e.g., pork, chicken, turkey), you can make that selection from the corresponding drop-down menu as well. Purchase meat products from farms that treat animals humanely. Rather than taking a gamble with each visit to a grocery store as to whether the meat you’re buying was raised humanely or not, purchase meat from farms that are known to have humane farming practices. Purchasing meat products from these farms will support them directly, and encourage further humane farming practices. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) maintains an online list which lists farms that use humane farming practices. View the list at: https://www.aspca.org/shopwithyourheart/consumer-resources/shop-your-heart-brand-list. All of the farms listed are “certified humane” or approved by the AWA or GAP. Consider purchasing humanely farmed animal products online. Some farms which treat their animals humanely are too small to distribute to different states. Humane farms whose products are available only online include: Wilde chicken jerky, pork from Belcamp Farm, and turkey from Anderson Ranches. Ask your local grocery stores to stock humanely farmed products. If you don’t see any products marked “certified humane” (or with the AWA or GAP logos) at your local grocery store, ask the managers if they’d be willing so start stocking humanely farmed meat products. Store managers are more likely to stock humane products if they know that a demand for these products exists among their customers. Access the template at: http://certifiedhumane.org/wp-content/uploads/Grocer-Request-Letter-2017c-1.pdf. Post on social media sites about supporting humane farming. Some of your professional contacts, friends, and family members may not be aware of the need for humane farming. For example, you could share an article on Facebook that describes humane farming practices and the ways they benefit animals’ health and well-being. Or, Tweet a link to a local farm that uses humane practices, and encourage friends and family to buy their meat from the farm.
